the Apulian shepherd changed into an oleaster: the Apulian shepherd is changed into an oleaster as punishment for mocking dancing nymphs (Ovid, Metamorphoses XIV 521)
Attis changed into a pine-tree: after castrating himself, Attis, the favourite of Cybele, is changed into a pine-tree (Ovid, Metamorphoses X 104)
Cyparissus changed into a cypress: when pining away for the loss of his favourite stag, Cyparissus the hunter, minion of Apollo, is changed into a cypress by the god (Ovid, Metamorphoses X 106)

Philemon and Baucis changed into oak and lime-tree: after having reached extreme old age, Philemon and Baucis are changed into an oak and a lime-tree whose boughs intertwine (Ovid, Metamorphoses VIII 712)
other metamorphoses of male persons into trees
metamorphoses of female persons into trees
Adonis' blood changed into an anemone or a rose: when Adonis is slain by a boar, Venus changes his blood into an anemone or a rose (Ovid, Metamorphoses X 735)
Ajax' blood changed into a hyacinth: after Ajax has taken his own life, his blood is changed into a hyacinth (Ovid, Metamorphoses X 207; XIII 390)
Ampelus changed into a vine: after having fallen to his death from a bull, Ampelus, the favourite of Bacchus, is changed into a vine
Attis' blood changed into violets: when Attis, the favourite of Cybele, castrates himself, his blood is changed into violets
Hyacinthus' blood changed into a hyacinth: when Hyacinthus is accidentally killed by Apollo with a discus, the god changes his blood into a hyacinth
Narcissus changed into a narcissus: when Narcissus is pining away for the love of his image reflected from the water, he is changed into a narcissus (Ovid, Metamorphoses III 510)
other metamorphoses of male persons into plants and flowers
metamorphoses of female persons into plants and flowers
Actaeon changed into a stag: as punishment for seeing her bathe, Diana changes Actaeon, the hunter, into a stag (Ovid, Metamorphoses III 193)
Cerastae changed into bullocks: because they sacrifice human beings to Jupiter, the Cerastae (horned people of Cyprus) are changed into bullocks by Venus (Ovid, Metamorphoses X 222)

horns growing on Cipus' head: when horns grow upon his head, Cipus, the Roman praetor, consults a diviner and is told that he must be king; but rather than destroy the Republican constitution he banishes himself (Ovid, Metamorphoses XV 565)

Lycaon changed into a wolf: Jupiter changes Lycaon into a wolf as punishment for offering the god, who is sitting at table, human flesh to eat; Lycaon's house is struck with lightning (Ovid, Metamorphoses I 237)
Lyncus changed into a lynx: Ceres changes Lyncus into a lynx when he is on the point of murdering the sleeping Triptolemus (Ovid, Metamorphoses V 657)
Midas given ass's ears: Apollo gives Midas ass's ears as punishment for preferring Pan in the musical contest between Apollo and Pan (Ovid, Metamorphoses XI 174)

Tyrrhenian sailors changed into dolphins: when Bacchus turns himself into a lion and has a vine grow about the ship, the Tyrrhenian sailors out of terror jump into the sea, and are metamorphosed into dolphins (Ovid, Metamorphoses III 662)
Ulysses' companions changed into swine: when they drink from the cup offered by Circe, the enchantress, Ulysses' companions change into swine (Ovid, Metamorphoses XIV 276)
other metamorphoses of male persons into mammals
metamorphoses of female persons into mammals
metamorphoses of male persons into birds (first series)
metamorphoses of male persons into birds (second series)
other metamorphoses of male persons into birds
metamorphoses of female persons into birds
Ascalabus (Stellio, Abas) changed into a lizard: Ceres changes the boy into a lizard as punishment for mocking her, when quenching her thirst too avidly (Ovid, Metamorphoses V 456)
Cadmus and Harmonia changed into snakes: when loaded with grief and the infirmity of old age, Cadmus and Harmonia are changed into snakes (Ovid, Metamorphoses IV 576)
Cerambus changed into a beetle: the nymphs change Cerambus into a beetle, so that the old man can escape Deucalion's flood (Ovid, Metamorphoses VII 353)

Lycian farmers changed into frogs: Latona changes Lycian farmers into frogs, because while they were weeding a marsh, they prevented her and her children from quenching their thirst (Ovid, Metamorphoses VI 369)
Tithonus changed into a cicada: when grown old and infirm, Tithonus is changed into a cicada by Aurora
other metamorphoses of male persons into (fabulous) animals
metamorphoses of female persons into (fabulous) animals
Battus changed into a touchstone: for violating the promise to keep Mercury's theft of Apollo's cattle a secret, Mercury turns Battus, the shepherd, into a touchstone (Ovid, Metamorphoses II 705)
Daphnis changed into a rock: a nymph changes Daphnis the shepherd into a rock, because he was unfaithful to her (Ovid, Metamorphoses IV 276)
Lichas changed into a rock: when hurled into the sea by Hercules, Lichas is changed into a rock (Ovid, Metamorphoses IX 219)
Sciron's bones changed into cliffs: when Sciron is slain by Theseus, his bones change into cliffs, because they were denied a resting-place both by land and sea (Ovid, Metamorphoses VII 444)
other metamorphoses of male persons into stone
metamorphoses of female persons into stone
Arcas changed into a constellation: when Arcas is about to shoot the bear into which his mother, Callisto, has been changed, Jupiter turns him into a constellation (Ovid, Metamorphoses II 506)
Dioscuri changed into a constellation: in reward of their brotherly love, the Dioscuri are changed into a constellation
Icarius changed into a constellation: after having been slain by angry farmers, Icarius is changed into a constellation (Ovid, Metamorphoses X 450)
Myrtilus changed into a constellation: when thrown into the sea by Pelops, Myrtilus, son of Mercury, is changed into a constellation
Orion changed into a constellation: while pursuing the Pleiades, or after his death, Orion is changed into a constellation (Ovid, Metamorphoses VIII 207; XIII 294)
other metamorphoses of male persons into stars and constellations
metamorphoses of female persons into stars and constellations
Acis changed into a river-god: when slain by Polyphemus, Acis is changed into a river-god by Galatea (Ovid, Metamorphoses XIII 885)
Alpheus changed into a river-god: when pining away for the love of Arethusa, Alpheus the hunter is changed into a river-god (Pausanias V 7, 2)
tears of Marsyas' friends changed into River Marsyas: when Marsyas' friends weep over Marsyas, flayed alive by Apollo, their tears change into the river Marsyas (Ovid, Metamorphoses VI 396)
Selemnus changed into a river-god: when pining away for the love of the nymph Argyra, Selemnus the shepherd is changed into a river-god
other metamorphoses of male persons into water, air or other elements
metamorphoses of female persons into water, air, or other elements
Asteria changed into an island: when she falls into the sea, Asteria, previously transformed into a quail, is changed into the island of Ortygia
Naiads changed into islands: as punishment for failing to invite him to their feast, Achelous changes the Naiads into the Echinades islands (Ovid, Metamorphoses VIII 583)
Perimele changed into an island: Perimele, when thrown into the sea by her father Hippodamas, is changed into an island by Neptune, at Achelous' request (Ovid, Metamorphoses VIII 609)
other metamorphoses of persons into islands
Caenis changed to Caeneus: when Neptune has ravished Caenis, he changes her at her request into the invulnerable hero Caeneus (Ovid, Metamorphoses XII 201)

Hermaphroditus and Salmacis changed into a hermaphrodite: at the prayer of the fountain-nymph Salmacis, who holds the bathing Hermaphroditus closely embraced, their bodies fuse (Ovid, Metamorphoses IV 373)
Iphis changed into a young man: in response to Iphis' prayer, Isis changes her into a young man to enable her to marry Ianthe (Ovid, Metamorphoses IX 785)
Me(s)tra changed into a fisherman: to support her father Erysichthon, Me(s)tra is changed into a fisherman by Neptune (Ovid, Metamorphoses VIII 853)

the ashes of Orion's daughters changed into two youths: after Orion's daughters have voluntarily sacrificed themselves, their ashes are changed into two youths: the Coroni (Ovid, Metamorphoses XIII 698)
other metamorphoses ~ sex
Bacchus' nurses are rejuvenated: at the request of Bacchus, who has witnessed Aeson's rejuvenation, his nurses are rejuvenated by Medea (Ovid, Metamorphoses VII 294)

Callirrhoe's sons age unnaturally: Callirrhoe's sons leap from infancy to manhood, a favour of Jupiter to enable them to revenge themselves on their father Alcmaeon's murderers, Phegeus and his sons (Ovid, Metamorphoses IX 432)
the Cumaean Sibyl is granted long life: Apollo grants the Cumaean Sibyl as many years as she has grains of sand in her hand, in return for her love (Ovid, Metamorphoses XIV 136)
Iolaus is rejuvenated: at Hercules' request, Hebe rejuvenates Iolaus (Ovid, Metamorphoses IX 399)
Phaon is rejuvenated: Phaon the boatman is rejuvenated as a reward for carrying Venus, in the guise of an old woman, over to Asia
other metamorphoses ~ age
Me(s)tra changed into various forms: to support her famished father Erysichthon, Me(s)tra changes herself into various forms (Ovid, Metamorphoses VIII 872)
ants changed to men: in answer to the prayer of Aeacus, Jupiter changes ants into men, the Myrmidons (Ovid, Metamorphoses VII 635)
bull changed to stag: to avoid detection of the theft of the bull by Bacchus' son, the bull is changed into a stag
Cerberus' foam changed into aconite: when Hercules drags Cerberus forth from Hades as his twelfth labour, Cerberus' foam turns into aconite (Ovid, Metamorphoses VII 418)
crow changed from white to black: because the crow has betrayed Coronis' infidelity, Apollo changes it from white to black (Ovid, Metamorphoses II 631)
Laelaps changed into stone: when Cephalus' dog, Laelaps, pursues the beast that plagued Thebes, they both turn into stone
Maera changed into a constellation: Maera, Erigone's dog, is changed into a constellation when pining away after the death of Icarius and Erigone
snake changed into stone

wolf turned to marble: at the prayer of Peleus and Thetis, a wolf is turned into marble by Psamathe because it had attacked the cattle that Peleus was herding on the sea-shore (Ovid, Metamorphoses X 401)
other metamorphoses of (fabulous) animals
a heron springs from the ashes of the city of Ardea (Ovid, Metamorphoses XIV 580)
a lance fixed by Romulus on the Palatine hill changes into a willow-tree (Ovid, Metamorphoses XV 561)
mulberries changing from white to red: when coloured by the blood of Pyramus and Thisbe, white mulberries become red (Ovid, Metamorphoses IV 158)
objects turning into grain, wine, oil: when touched by Anius' daughters, objects turn into grain, wine and oil; a gift from Bacchus (Ovid, Metamorphoses XIII 650)
statue coming to life: at Pygmalion's prayer, a statue (latterly called Galatea) comes to life; a favour of Venus (Ovid, Metamorphoses X 280)
stones turning into men: stones thrown by Deucalion and Pyrrha, as directed by the oracle of Themis, turn into men (Ovid, Metamorphoses X 400)
objects turning to gold: because of Midas' kindness to Silenus, the things he touches turn into gold; a gift from Bacchus (Midas may be seen at table, trying to eat) (Ovid, Metamorphoses XI 92)
other metamorphoses of objects, plants or flowers

Jason and the Argonauts meeting Aeetes, king of Colchis
meeting of Jason and Medea: she falls in love with him at first sight, possibly with Cupid shooting an arrow at Medea
Jason and Medea at the altar of Hecate (or Diana): Medea gives him a magic herb or ointment
Jason hitches the fire-breathing bulls to the plough
after ploughing, Jason sows dragon's teeth; armed men emerge
fight with the dragon; Jason sprinkles a drug in its eyes, possibly assisted by Medea
the Argonauts and Medea go aboard, pursued by the Colchians
the murder of Apsyrtus
the Argonauts with Alcinous, king of the Phaeacians
the Argo safely passes the Sirens, whilst Orpheus plays his lyre
the Argonauts stranded in Libya
Talus, the bronze giant sentinel of Crete, is overcome by Medea's spells, and captured by Castor and Pollux
the Argo, caught in a storm, is safely beached; Jason pours a libation on an altar to Apollo and is mocked by Medea's twelve maidens
Medea and her twelve maidens enter Iolcus in disguise with a statue of Diana
rejuvenation of Aeson
Medea's vengeance on Pelias

the sons of the seven heroes of the first Theban war, i.e. Aegialeus, Alcmaeon, Amphilochus (alternatively Polydorus or Euryalus), Diomedes, Promachus, Sthenelus and Thersander, decide to take up arms against Thebes

the return of Paris to Troy; he follows the bull which is to be the prize in the funeral games organized by Priam
Paris in Greece
Paris and Helen in Troy
Ulysses feigns madness: he ploughs with an ox and an ass yoked together, and at the same time sows salt; Palamedes places the young Telemachus in front of the plough, which makes Ulysses give in
Achilles discovered among the daughters of Lycomedes, i.e. Achilles on Scyros: when presents are brought Achilles snatches up the weapons and thus betrays his identity
the Greek fleet is supplied by Anius, king of Delos, and his daughters
sacrifice to Jupiter and Apollo: a snake swallows a nest of eight young birds and their mother; the augur Calchas explains the portent
Iphigenia, daughter of Agamemnon, is fetched from home
the Greeks on Tenedos
Philoctetes, wounded in the foot, is left behind
the Greeks in Mysia, they fight against Telephus and his men
a Greek embassy is sent to Priam
Protesilaus, who leaps ashore first, is killed by Hector
Achilles kills Cycnus by strangling him with his helmet-thongs
Achilles watches Troilus, Priam's son, at the horse-trough; sometimes Polyxena present
the Greeks ravage the Trojan countryside
Palamedes is falsely accused of treachery by Ulysses
the ransom of Chryseis: Agamemnon refuses to return Chryseis to her father Chryses
Briseis is taken away from Achilles and led to Agamemnon by the heralds Talthybius and Eurybates; Achilles may be holding a lyre
the dream of Agamemnon: Morpheus, in the shape of Nestor, urges him to attack
the Greeks rush to their ships; Ulysses and Minerva prevent the army from withdrawing
Thersites insults Agamemnon and is punished by Ulysses, who strikes him with his sceptre
Paris and Menelaus duelling
Venus intervenes in the duel between Paris and Menelaus: she covers Paris with a cloud and leads him to his room
the truce is broken by Pandarus, who wounds Menelaus
heroic deeds of Diomedes ~ Trojan war
Hector encounters his mother Hecuba on his way to Paris
Hecuba and the Trojan women pray in Minerva's temple
Hector rebukes Paris in Helen's presence
Hector's farewell to his wife Andromache and his young son Astyanax

grief of Achilles at the news of Patroclus' death
Briseis is brought back to Achilles
departure of Achilles for the battle-field

Achilles fights the river-gods Scamander and Simois; Achilles is assisted by Vulcan, who dries up the waters with scorching flames
Hector's last fight and death
the spirit of Patroclus appears to Achilles
Achilles slays Trojan captives
funeral games in honour of Patroclus
Iris advises Priam to obtain Hector's body
Hector's body is weighed in gold (Aeschylus)
the body of Hector is brought back to Troy

Memnon, Aurora's son, comes to the aid of the Trojans
death of Achilles
Ulysses gets the arms of Achilles
madness of Ajax: he slaughters the Greek cattle

the Greeks prepare to leave Troy

scenes from the Trojan war that cannot be located in the chronological sequence of the story, featuring the Trojans

Ulysses departs from the island of Circe and passes through a series of dangers, which Circe had warned him about (Homer, Odyssey XII)
Ulysses is kindly received by the nymph Calypso on the island of Ogygia (Homer, Odyssey XII)
Ulysses sails on his raft (Homer, Odyssey V)
Ulysses with the Phaeacians (Homer, Odyssey VI-VIII)

Telemachus and Ulysses meet in Eumaeus' hut (Homer, Odyssey XVI)
Telemachus returns to the palace, where he meets his mother
on his way to the town Ulysses is reviled by Melanthius, the goatherd (Homer, Odyssey XVII)
Ulysses is recognized by his dog Argus
Ulysses, still in beggar's guise, arrives in the palace
Minerva appears to the sleeping Penelope and enhances her beauty
during the night Ulysses and Telemachus remove all the weapons from the hall (Homer, Odyssey XIX)
meeting of Ulysses and Penelope, who fails to recognize him
Ulysses, at the banquet with the suitors, is ridiculed again (Homer, Odyssey XX)
Penelope announces she will marry the man who can shoot an arrow through twelve axe-rings, and produces Ulysses' bow (Homer, Odyssey XXI)
several attempts are made by the suitors of Penelope to string the bow; Penelope retires
Ulysses seizes the bow, strings it and shoots through the twelve axe-rings
Ulysses, assisted by Telemachus, kills the suitors (Homer, Odyssey XXII)
the punishment of the guilty servants ~ Ulysses back in Ithaca
Euryclea fetches Penelope
bath of Ulysses; Minerva enhances his looks
Penelope and Ulysses embrace

Mercury brings the souls of the suitors to Hades

Menelaus (disguised in seal skins, as directed by Eidothea) falls upon Proteus who tries to avoid answering his questions by assuming different shapes
Menelaus and Helen back in Sparta
Ajax the Lesser shipwrecked; while he is scrambling ashore Neptune splits the rocks with his trident
Idomeneus had vowed to sacrifice the first creature he would meet in Crete should he return safely; on arrival this proves to be his son

Hercules discovers Tiryns' famous dye: the muzzle of Hercules' dog is stained with purple after it has bitten into a mollusc

Hercules as personification of Virtue
Hercules at the cross-roads, 'Herkules am Scheidewege': the choice of Hercules
Hercules Gallicus: he captivates his audience with a golden chain going from his mouth to their ears

Perigune, the daughter of Sinis, hides in a thicket of asparagus-plants after Theseus had killed her father; she falls in love with Theseus
Theseus in love with Phaedra, Minos' daughter
the Athenian youths draw lots for the yearly tribute to Crete: seven youths and seven maidens to be devoured by the Minotaur
Theseus goes to Crete among the chosen victims

Theseus' dispute with King Minos: Minos proves himself a son of Jupiter, his prayer is answered by thunder; Theseus proves himself a son of Neptune, he jumps into the sea and brings back the ring Minos threw into it
Ariadne gives Theseus a ball of thread
Theseus, with the ball of thread, finds his way into the Labyrinth
Theseus sails away, carrying Ariadne with him
Theseus' ship, with black sails, approaches Athens; Aegeus casts himself into the sea

Theseus killing various animals

Theseus is received amicably by Hecale (Hecalene) on his return from capturing the bull of Marathon
Pirithous and Theseus come forward between their hostile armies and embrace
Theseus and Pirithous descending into Hades to carry off Proserpina
in consequence of a sedition, Theseus curses the Athenians and leaves Athens for Scyros
death of Theseus: King Lycomedes of Scyros pushes Theseus from a cliff

Perseus goes to the three Graeae; while they are asleep he steals the one eye and the one tooth they share between them

the Dioscuri in Attica: they fetch Helen, whom Theseus had carried off
death of Castor: the Dioscuri fight Idas and Lynceus in a quarrel about some cattle, or about the rape of the daughters of Leucippus; Idas, Lynceus and Castor are killed

Bellerophon bridles Pegasus
Bellerophon, flying on Pegasus' back, kills the Chimera, a fire-breathing monster, with arrows or a spear
Bellerophon and Pegasus fight the Solymians
Bellerophon and Pegasus fight the Amazons
Bellerophon beats off a band of Carian pirates
when noticing Iobates' life-guard lying in wait for him, Bellerophon prays to Neptune, who floods the Xanthian plain
Bellerophon's fall: in an attempt to fly to Heaven, he is flung off Pegasus' back
Bellerophon wandering about the earth, lame, blind, lonely and accursed

suffering, misfortune of Bellerophon - apotheosis, deification

Oedipus at the oracle of Delphi in order to find out the truth about his parents
Oedipus meets his father Laius, who is on a journey to Delphi; as Oedipus refuses to move aside for his carriage, a quarrel arises
Oedipus and the sphinx; he solves the riddle
Oedipus becomes king of Thebes

Aeneas leaves the country of Troy
stay of Aeneas on Thrace: miracle of the bleeding bush on Polydorus' grave; the spirit of Polydorus advises Aeneas to flee
stay of Aeneas on Delos: meeting with Anius, and consultation of the Delian oracle; the Trojans offer sacrifices to the gods
stay of Aeneas on Crete: a pestilence ravages the Trojans
stay of Aeneas on the Strophades Islands: fight with the Harpies that befoul the crew's food
sacrifices are made to Jupiter and games are held on the shore of Actium by Aeneas and his crew
stay of Aeneas on Epirus, where the Trojans find Helenus established as king and married to Andromache
first stay of Aeneas in Sicily
Aeneas' fleet cast on the coast of Libya
the meeting of Aeneas and Achates with Venus, disguised as a huntress; she points out twelve swans in the sky
Aeneas and Achates reach Carthage, where building is in progress
the meeting of Aeneas and Dido; when he approaches her throne, the cloud enveloping him and Achates vanishes
the banquet of Aeneas and Dido
Dido tormented by her love for Aeneas
Dido and Aeneas hunting
the Trojans' departure from Carthage
Aeneas and his companions meet with Acestes, their kinsman
celebration of the anniversary of the death of Anchises
Iris, in the guise of Beroe, an old woman, incites the Trojan women to rebellion; they set the ships on fire
Aeneas' departure from Sicily
the arrival of Aeneas at Cumae, where they consult Deiphobe, the Cumaean Sibyl, who foretells of Aeneas' wars in Latium
returning to the beach the Trojans find Misenus, the trumpet blower, dead
Aeneas plucks the 'Golden Bough' by the aid of two doves
Aeneas' visit to the underworld
the Trojans eat cakes of bread which they have used as platters; thus fulfilling the Harpy's prophecy; they hail their new fatherland
the Trojans with King Latinus
Juno goes to Alecto, the Fury, to arouse sedition
the Italian tribes gather to expel the Trojans ~ Aeneid
Aeneas secures help for the Trojans
Venus asks Vulcan to forge Aeneas' armour
the siege of the Trojan camp ~ battle of Latium (Virgil, Aeneid IX)
the return of Aeneas and the Relief ~ battle of Latinum (Virgil, Aeneid X)
respite of the battle of Latium
battle in Latium after the breaking of the truce
last deeds of Turnus
scenes from the Aeneid that cannot be located in the chronological sequence of the story, featuring the Trojans
scenes from the Aeneid that cannot be located in the chronological sequence of the story, featuring the Latins
Daphne changed into a laurel-tree: while fleeing from Apollo, Daphne is changed into a laurel-tree by her father Peneus (Ovid, Metamorphoses I 548)

Heliades changed into poplar-trees: while weeping over Phaeton's grave the Heliades are changed into poplar-trees, and their tears turn into beads of amber; their mother Clymene may be present (Ovid, Metamorphoses II 346)
Leucothea changed into an incense bush: Apollo, Leucothea's lover, having tried in vain to recall her to life, changes Leucothea into an incense bush (Ovid, Metamorphoses IV 252)
Myrrha changed into a myrtle-tree: when fleeing from her father's wrath, Myrrha is changed into a myrtle-tree (Ovid, Metamorphoses X 489)
Philyra changed into a lime-tree: at the birth of Chiron, her son by Saturn, Philyra is changed into a lime-tree for shame of Chiron's appearance
Phyllis changed into an almond-tree: after having killed herself in despair for Demophon's absence, Phyllis is changed into an almond-tree
Pitys changed into a pine-tree: while fleeing from Pan, Pitys is changed into a pine-tree
Thracian women changed into oak-trees: for murdering Orpheus, the Thracian (Ciconian) women are changed into oak-trees by Bacchus (Ovid, Metamorphoses XI 70)
other metamorphoses of female persons into trees
Clytie changed into a sunflower: on account of Apollo's contempt the Oceanid Clytie changes into a sunflower (heliotrope) (Ovid, Metamorphoses IV 268)

Dryope changed into a lotus-plant: Dryope is changed into a lotus-plant, when to please her little boy she picks a flower from a lotus-plant (i.e. Lotis metamorphosed) which then starts to bleed (Ovid, Metamorphoses IX 331)
Lotis changed into a lotus-plant: while fleeing from Priapus, Lotis is changed into a lotus-plant (Ovid, Metamorphoses IX 347)
Minthe changed into a mint-plant: when Pluto tries to seduce Minthe, the nymph is changed into a mint-plant through the jealousy of Proserpina
Syrinx changed into a reed: while fleeing from Pan, the nymph Syrinx is changed into reed by her sisters, the Naiads (Ovid, Metamorphoses I 705)
other metamorphoses of female persons into plants and flowers
Actaeon as a stag is devoured by his own dogs
Lycaon is changed into a wolf when attempting to kill Jupiter, who is lying in bed
Lycaon's fifty sons are changed into wolves
Midas' barber, unable to keep the secret of Midas' ass's ears, whispers it into a hole in the ground; reeds grow from this hole and disclose Midas' secret to all the world when moved by the wind
Ulysses' companions are changed into all kinds of animals
Atalante and Hippomenes changed into lions: when they profane the temple of Cybele, Atalante and Hippomenes are changed into lions by the goddess (Ovid, Metamorphoses X 689)
Callisto changed into a bear: Juno changes Callisto, who is attending the young Arcas (her son by Jupiter), into a bear
women of Cos changed into cows: when the women of Cos insult Juno in their anger about Hercules driving Geryon's cattle through their fields, they are changed into cows (Ovid, Metamorphoses VII 363)
Galanthis changed into a weasel: Juno changes Galanthis into a weasel for having deceived her about Alcmene's labour (Ovid, Metamorphoses IX 306)
Hecuba changed into a dog: while being stoned, Hecuba is changed into a dog (Ovid, Metamorphoses XIII 567)
Io changed into a cow: to avoid detection by Juno, Jupiter changes Io into a cow (Ovid, Metamorphoses I 611)

Minyas' daughters changed into bats: having aroused Bacchus' anger by weaving instead of worshipping him, the daughters of Minyas, Leuconoe (Leucippe), Alcithoe and Arsippe, are changed into bats by the god (Ovid, Metamorphoses IV 399)
Ocyroe changed into a mare: when she is foretelling the fates of her father Chiron and the young Aesculapius, Ocyroe is changed into a mare (Ovid, Metamorphoses II 657)
other metamorphoses of female persons into mammals

Aesacus changed into a diving bird: in despair for having caused the death of Hesperia (or Asterope), Aesacus throws himself into the sea and is changed into a diving bird by Tethys (Ovid, Metamorphoses XI 783)
Argus' eyes changed into peacock's 'eyes' (ocelli): Juno sets Argus' eyes on her peacock, after Argus, while watching Io, has been slain by Mercury (Ovid, Metamorphoses I 723)

Ascalaphus changed into a screech-owl: as punishment for discovering she had eaten some pomegranates, Proserpina sprinkles water from the Phlegethon on Ascalaphus' head, thus changing him into a screech-owl (Ovid, Metamorphoses V 543)
Botres changed into a bee-eater: when Botres is slain by his father Eumelus for disturbing his sacrifice to Apollo, the god changes him into a bee-eater (Ovid, Metamorphoses VII 390)
Caeneus changed into a bird: when Caeneus, originally a girl (Caenis), is killed in the battle of the Lapiths and centaurs, he is changed into a bird (Ovid, Metamorphoses XII 522)

Cygnus, son of Apollo, changed into a swan: because his friend Phil(l)ius refused to give him the bull captured by the help of Hercules, Cycnus, the son of Apollo, leaps off a cliff, and is changed into a swan (Ovid, Metamorphoses VII 371)
Cygnus, son of Neptune, changed into a swan: when Achilles arrives in Trojan country he strangles Cycnus, son of Neptune; Cycnus is changed into a swan by his father (Ovid, Metamorphoses XII 144)
Cycnus, son of Sthenelus, changed into a swan: while grieving over the death of Phaethon, Cycnus, son of Sthenelus, is changed into a swan (Ovid, Metamorphoses II 373)
Daedalion changed into a hawk: while leaping from a cliff, crazed by the death of his daughter Chione, Daedalion is changed into a hawk by Apollo (Ovid, Metamorphoses XI 339)
Diomedes' companions changed into herons: because they have insulted her, Venus changes Diomedes' companions into herons (Ovid, Metamorphoses XIV 494)
Hierax changed into a hawk: Mercury changes Hierax into a hawk, as punishment for informing Argus that the god was stealing Io
Memnon's ashes changed into birds: Memnon's ashes are changed into birds, the Memnonides; they rise from Memnon's funeral pyre and fight around his tomb (Ovid, Metamorphoses XIII 608)
Molussus and family changed into birds: Jupiter changes Molossus and his family into birds to save them from their house, which is set on fire by robbers (Ovid, Metamorphoses XIII 717)
Nisus changed into a fish-hawk: when killing himself after having been betrayed by his daughter Scylla, Nisus is changed into a fish-hawk (Ovid, Metamorphoses VIII 145)
Perdix changed into a partridge: when Perdix (Talus) is thrown from the Acropolis by the envious Daedalus, Minerva changes him into a partridge (Ovid, Metamorphoses VIII 250)

Periphas and Phene changed into eagle and fish-hawk: Jupiter, at Apollo's request, changes Periphas and Phene into an eagle and a fish-hawk instead of slaying them for having aroused his enmity (Ovid, Metamorphoses VII 400)
Picus changed into a woodpecker: Circe changes Picus into a woodpecker because, faithful to his wife Canens, he spurns the love of the goddess (Ovid, Metamorphoses XIV 386)
metamorphoses of female persons into birds (first series)
metamorphoses of female persons into birds (second series)
other metamorphoses of female persons into birds
Arachne changed into a spider: when hanging herself after having been defeated in a weaving contest with Minerva, Arachne is changed into a spider by the goddess (Ovid, Metamorphoses VI 135)
Proserpina's companions changed into sirens: Ceres changes Proserpina's companions into sirens, so that they may search for Proserpina over the sea (Ovid, Metamorphoses V 552)
Scylla changed into a sea-monster: Circe, to whom Glaucus has applied for aid in his love suit, changes Scylla the sea-nymph into a sea-monster (Ovid, Metamorphoses XIV 59)
other metamorphoses of female persons into (fabulous) animals
Daphnis, blinded by the nymph, is turned into a stone by Mercury
Aglauros changed into a stone: Mercury changes Aglauros into a stone because she prevents him from entering Herse's room (Ovid, Metamorphoses II 820)
Anaxarete changed into a stone: while looking from her window at Iphis' funeral, Anaxarete is changed into a stone (Ovid, Metamorphoses XIV 753)
Cinyras' daughters changed into temple steps: for comparing themselves to Juno, Cinyras' daughters are changed into temple steps (Ovid, Metamorphoses VI 98)
Lethaea and Olenus changed into stones: on account of their pride, Lethaea and her husband Olenus are changed into stones (Ovid, Metamorphoses X 70)
Niobe changed into stone: in her grief for the loss of her children, Niobe is changed into a stone (Ovid, Metamorphoses VI 305)

Propoetides changed into stones: driven to prostitution by the wrath of Venus, whose divinity they denied, the Propoetides, women of Amathus, are changed into stones for their impudence (Ovid, Metamorphoses X 238)

Rhodope and Haemus changed into mountains: because they insolently likened themselves to Juno and Jupiter, Rhodope and her brother-husband Haemus are changed into mountains (Ovid, Metamorphoses VI 87)
Theban woman changed into stones: Juno changes the Theban women who are grieving for the loss of Ino into stones (Ovid, Metamorphoses IV 561)
other metamorphoses of female persons into stone
Callisto changed into a constellation: Jupiter changes Callisto into a constellation, when, transformed into a bear she is about to be shot by Arcas (Ovid, Metamorphoses II 506)
Erigone changed into a constellation: when hanging herself through grief at the death of her father Icarius, Erigone is changed into a constellation (Ovid, Metamorphoses X 451)
other metamorphoses of female persons into stars and constellations
Arethusa changed into a fountain: Diana changes her attendant Arethusa into a fountain, after first having hidden her in a cloud to escape Alpheus, the river-god (Ovid, Metamorphoses V 621)
Byblis changed into a fountain: after looking for Caunus everywhere, Byblis at last lies down, bathed in tears, and is changed into a fountain (Ovid, Metamorphoses IX 663)
Canens changed into air and water: while grieving for the loss of Picus, her husband, Canens is changed into air and water (Ovid, Metamorphoses XIV 431)
Cyane changed into a fountain: when trying to stop Pluto from abducting Proserpina, the nymph Cyane is changed into a fountain (Ovid, Metamorphoses V 411)
Echo changed into a voice: when pining away on account of Narcissus, the nymph Echo is changed into a voice; at the same time her bones turn into stone (Ovid, Metamorphoses III 398)
Egeria changed into a fountain: when Egeria's grief at the death of Numa Pompilius can not be assuaged, she melts away in tears, and is changed into a fountain (Ovid, Metamorphoses XV 546)
Hyrie changed into a fountain: in her grief for the loss of Cycnus, her son by Apollo, Hyrie is changed into a fountain (Ovid, Metamorphoses VII 380)
Pirene changed into a fountain: when pining away for the loss of her son Cenchreus, who inadvertently had been killed by Diana, Pirene is changed into a fountain on Mount Helicon
other metamorphoses of female persons into water, air, or other elements
any man bathing in the pool Salmacis becomes a hermaphrodite
the Cumaean Sibyl, having spurned Apollo, becomes hideously old: when reduced to a tiny thing she is hung up in a bottle and becomes a mere voice
Laelaps turns into stone as he helps Amphitryon to catch the Teumessian fox, which also petrifies
a snake is turned into stone by Apollo as it attacks Orpheus' severed head washed ashore (Ovid, Metamorphoses XI 58)
a snake is turned into stone by Jupiter, after swallowing eight young birds and their mother (when the Greeks are assembled in Aulis before sailing to Troy)

banquets, feasts of the gods (in the air, possibly on the clouds)
banquets, feasts of the gods (on the sea)
nectar (food of the gods)
ambrosia (food of the gods)
assemblies of the gods in the air, possibly on the clouds
assemblies of the gods on the sea
the Lemnian women meeting the Argonauts
Jason and Hypsipyle
Hercules chiding the Argonauts and forcing them back to the boat
the Argo's guards attacked by the giants
the Argonauts kill Cyzicus and his men, by accident, in the dark
Hylas abducted by the nymphs whilst fetching water
Hercules searching for Hylas
the Argonauts sailing away leaving Hercules behind
boxing-match between the Bebrycian king Amycus and Pollux
Calais and Zetes chase away the Harpies that plagued Phineus
Calais and Zetes free Phineus' two sons from prison
Phineus, bringing doves, instructs the Argonauts how to navigate further
Medea, conscience-stricken
Jason ploughs all day
the dragon-men kill each other when Jason throws a stone among them
the Golden Fleece, hanging on an oak-tree, is seized by Jason
Apsyrtus is murdered by Medea, who throws his limbs overboard
Apsyrtus, trapped by Medea, is killed by Jason
Jason and Medea purified from the murder of Apsyrtus by Circe
wedding of Jason and Medea; the Golden Fleece is spread over the bed
the Argonauts carry the ship on their shoulders to Lake Tritonis
the god Triton takes the tripod from the Argonauts
Triton draws the Argo by the keel from the lake to the sea
Medea prays alone in the night; her chariot, drawn by winged dragons, is sent to enable her to pick magic herbs
Medea builds two altars, one to Hecate and another to Hebe, and kills a black sheep
Aeson is laid down before Medea; she brews a potion in a bronze pot (an old and dry olive-branch becomes green when stirred in it)
Aeson's throat is cut, his old blood runs out, his veins are filled with Medea's brew, and he is rejuvenated
Medea boils an old ram in a cauldron: a young lamb comes out; the daughters of Pelias watch the scene
the daughters of Pelias kill their father in his bed; Medea plunges his body in boiling water
Polynices, banished from Thebes by his brother Eteocles, comes to Argos
Tydeus, son of Oeneus, banished for homicide from Calydon, comes to Argos
Polynices and Tydeus quarrel in the royal palace (the former displaying a lion on his shield, the latter a boar); Adrastus, king of Argos, stops the fight
Polynices and Tydeus marry Argia and Deipyle, the daughters of Adrastus
Adrastus musters an army to attack Thebes and appoints six other chiefs; these are, according to the general account: Amphiaraus, Capaneus, Hippomedon, Parthenopaeus, Polynices and Tydeus

Amphiaraus being reluctant, Polynices bribes Eriphyle, Amphiaraus' wife, with the necklace formerly belonging to Harmonia; Eriphyle discloses Amphiaraus' hiding-place and he is thus compelled to join the enterprise
the army at Nemea
Tydeus is sent as herald and defeats the Theban leaders one by one in single combat
each of the seven gates of Thebes is apportioned to one of the Argive chiefs
Tiresias predicting the fate of Thebes
death of Capaneus: while climbing the wall of Thebes he is struck down by Jupiter's thunderbolt
Tydeus is mortally wounded by Melanippus, who is subsequently slain
single combat between Eteocles and Polynices; they both die
flight of Amphiaraus; he is swallowed up by the earth
Adrastus escapes on Arion, the winged horse
Creon, king of Thebes, forbids the burial of the enemies' corpses
Theseus marches with an army against Creon
scenes from the story of the Seven against Thebes that cannot be located in the chronological sequence of the story, featuring the Seven against Thebes
scenes from the story of the Seven against Thebes that cannot be located in the chronological sequence of the story, featuring the Thebans
Eriphyle is bribed by Thersander, son of Polynices, with the magic robe formerly belonging to Harmonia, to induce her son Alcmaeon to go with the Epigoni
battle before the walls of Thebes; Aegialeus is killed
the Thebans escape with their wives and children during the night
Alcmaeon kills Eriphyle, his mother
Alcmaeon flees, pursued by the Furies
in Arcadia Alcmaeon is purified by King Phegeus and marries Arsinoe, Phegeus' daughter; he gives her Harmonia's robe and necklace
having to leave Arcadia, Alcmaeon is purified again by the river-god Achelous; he marries Achelous' daughter Callirrhoe and promises her the necklace of Harmonia
Alcmaeon asks Phegeus to surrender Harmonia's robe and necklace
the sons of Callirrhoe avenge their father Alcmaeon by killing Phegeus and his sons
scenes from the story of the Epigoni that cannot be located in the chronological sequence of the story, featuring the Epigoni
scenes from the story of the Epigoni that cannot be located in the chronological sequence of the story, featuring the Thebans
the three goddesses Venus, Juno and Minerva quarrel about the golden apple; Jupiter sends them to Paris
Mercury brings Paris the golden apple
the Judgement of Paris (Mercury present)
the recognition of Paris: when attacked by one of his jealous brothers, Cassandra reveals Paris' identity
Paris is recognized and accepted by Priam
Paris encounters Helen during a festival of Venus
Paris at the court of Menelaus
the abduction of Helen and some of her companions: Paris carries them off by sea, and takes a part of the palace-treasure with him
the arrival of Paris and Helen at Troy
the triumph of Paris and Helen
Helen presented to Priam
marriage of Paris and Helen
Anius' daughters are forced to embark with the Greeks
Agamemnon shoots Diana's favourite stag
the sacrifice of Iphigenia
Tenes, who hurls a rock on the ships, is killed by Achilles
Philoctetes is bitten by a snake
Philoctetes is wounded by one of Hercules' arrows
Telephus is wounded by Achilles, with the help of Bacchus, who causes Telephus to stumble over a vine
Antenor, one of the elders of Troy, and his wife Theano receive the envoys
Achilles kills Troilus in the temple of Apollo
the capture of Briseis and Chryseis
gold is found in Palamedes' tent
Palamedes is stoned to death by the Greeks
Chryses' prayer to Apollo
Apollo sends a pestilence into the Greek camp
council of the Greeks: Minerva restrains Achilles' anger by seizing him by the hair; possibly Nestor trying to calm Agamemnon
Chryseis is returned to her father
Achilles withdraws from the war and complains to his mother Thetis
Thetis asks Jupiter to support her son (Achilles)
Priam and Helen, whom Iris fetched in the likeness of Laodice, on the wall of Troy
Venus fetches Helen and brings her to Paris
Helen scorns Paris
Menelaus is cured by Machaon
Diomedes kills Pandarus
Aeneas tries to save the body of Pandarus but is hit by a stone thrown by Diomedes; Venus comes to Aeneas' rescue
Mars is wounded by Diomedes, who is assisted by Minerva
Diomedes and Glaucus exchange arms (Iliad VI)
Ulysses and Diomedes intercept and kill Dolon, a Trojan spy
Ulysses and Diomedes kill Rhesus and his companions and take away his horses
Juno requests Venus' girdle
Juno in the House of Sleep: she asks Hypnos' assistance
Jupiter is lured away by Juno wearing Venus' girdle
during Jupiter's absence Neptune turns the battle in favour of the Greeks
Jupiter awakes and restores order
Sarpedon is killed by Patroclus
the body of Sarpedon is carried through the air by Hypnos and Thanatos
the fight over the body of Patroclus
Menelaus carries Patroclus' body from the battle-field
Achilles mourning over the body of Patroclus
arming of Achilles
arming of Hector; Andromache, Priam and others implore him not to fight
Hector awaits Achilles outside the Trojan wall
Achilles pursues Hector around the wall of the city
Achilles kills Hector
Hector's body, tied to Achilles' chariot, is dragged around the city
Priam on his way to Achilles' tent, guided by Mercury
Hector's tomb
Achilles kills Thersites, who mocks him for mourning Penthesilea
Memnon kills Antilochus
Memnon is killed by Achilles
Achilles is killed by Paris in the temple of Apollo
Achilles is killed on the battle-field by Paris, who shoots an arrow in his heel
Thetis mourning Achilles
Teucer finds the dead Ajax
Philoctetes is cured of his wounds by Machaon or Podalirius
Philoctetes shoots Paris with an arrow
Neoptolemus receives Achilles' arms
Antenor's treason
Ulysses before Helen in Troy
the Trojan horse
Greek warriors conceal themselves in the wooden horse
the other Greeks break camp
Laocoon, the priest, tries to dissuade the Trojans from bringing the horse inside the walls, and hurls a spear at it
Sinon, a Greek pretending to be a deserter, is brought in
Laocoon and his twin sons are strangled by two serpents during the preparations for a sacrifice
the Trojans celebrate the victory
Menelaus' meeting with Helen
Priam, Hecuba and their daughters take refuge at the altar of Jupiter in the courtyard of the palace
Cassandra, sheltering in Minerva's temple (sometimes with Andromache), is dragged away by Ajax the Lesser, while she holds the image of the goddess
Astyanax is snatched away from Andromache
Neoptolemus gets Andromache as his prize
Polyxena is sacrificed by Neoptolemus on Achilles' tomb
Agamemnon gets Cassandra as his prize
Ulysses wins Hecuba as his prize
Polyphemus, returning with his flocks, discovers the Greeks in his cave
Polyphemus devours some of Ulysses' companions
Ulysses offers wine to Polyphemus
Polyphemus is blinded with a pointed stake
Ulysses and his men slip away concealed under rams
Polyphemus hurls a rock at Ulysses' departing ships
Ulysses receives a bag containing the adverse winds
while Ulysses is asleep, his companions open the bag; contrary winds rush out
Circe invites Ulysses' men into her palace
Mercury gives Ulysses the magic herb 'moly', a countercharm
Ulysses at the house of Circe; she begs for mercy after Ulysses has resisted her drugged cup
Ulysses, waiting sword in hand, sees the ghost of Elpenor
Ulysses and the ghost of Tiresias, who tells him about the future
Ulysses meets the ghosts of numerous queens, princesses, heroes, comrades, including his mother Anticlea
Ulysses, tied to the mast of his ship, passes the Sirens
Ulysses passes Scylla and Charybdis; Scylla devours six of his men
in Thrinacria Ulysses' men devour some of the cattle of the Sun-god while Ulysses is asleep
Ulysses escapes from Charybdis by clinging to a fig-tree
Mercury orders Calypso to release Ulysses (Homer, Odyssey V)
Ulysses builds a raft
Neptune raises a storm and destroys Ulysses' raft
Leucothea, in the guise of a sea-gull, gives Ulysses a scarf to wind around his waist
Ulysses is cast ashore on the island of Scheria
Minerva appears to Nausicaa in a dream
Nausicaa on her way to the sea-shore with her companions
meeting of Nausicaa and Ulysses: Ulysses, almost naked, comes out of the bushes; Nausicaa and her companions are startled at the sight
Ulysses at Alcinous' court
Minerva, disguised as Mentes, comes to encourage Telemachus
the meeting of the people of Ithaca; Telemachus demands that the suitors leave
Telemachus starts out with Mentor, in search of his father
Telemachus in Pylus
Telemachus and Pisistratus, son of Nestor, in Sparta with Menelaus and Helen
Penelope weaving Laertes' shroud (Homer, Odyssey II 94-100; XIX 138-155)
Ulysses awakes on the shore where the Phaeacians left him; Minerva disguises him as an old beggar (Homer, Odyssey XIII)
Ulysses meets Eumaeus, the old swine-herd, and goes to the latter's hut (Homer, Odyssey XIV)
on Minerva's command Telemachus and Pisistratus leave Sparta
the seer Theoclymenus joins Telemachus' party
Telemachus and his travel companions tell Penelope their adventures, while Penelope is engaged in spinning (Homer, Odyssey XVII)
in the banqueting hall of the palace Ulysses is mistreated by the suitors; Antinous hurls a stool at him
Ulysses' fight with Irus, the beggar (Homer, Odyssey XVIII)
Penelope soothes the suitors and receives their gifts
Ulysses is recognized by Euryclea while she is washing his feet
Ulysses meets his father Laertes, who is hoeing in the vineyard
the murder of Agamemnon: he is killed when sitting at a banquet
Clytaemnestra kills Cassandra
Ajax the Lesser shipwrecked; while he is scrambling ashore Minerva splits the rocks with Jupiter's thunderbolt
Idomeneus sacrifices his own child
Alcmene exposes the baby (Hercules) outside Thebes
Hercules strangles two serpents in his cradle
Hercules instructed by various persons
Hercules shoots Nessus, the centaur, who attempts to carry off Deianira
Hercules and Deianira with the dying Nessus
Deianira alone with the dying Nessus, who advises her to keep some of his blood
Iole is carried away by Hercules during the war he made against her father, Eurytus of Oechalia
Hercules, in female garment, kicks Pan from Omphale's bed
Hercules consults the Delphic oracle and is bidden to go and serve King Eurystheus of Tiryns
(1) Hercules chokes the Nemean lion with his arms
(2) the Hydra of Lerna is killed by Hercules
(3) the Ceryneian hind of Arcadia is captured by Hercules
(4) the Erymanthian boar is captured by Hercules
(5) Hercules cleanses the stables of Augeas by diverting the rivers Alpheus and Peneus
(6) the Stymphalian birds are shot by Hercules, or driven away with a bronze rattle
(7) the Cretan bull is captured by Hercules
(8) the four mares of King Diomedes are captured; when Diomedes is slain in the ensuing battle his body is thrown to the mares to eat
(9) Hippolyte, the Amazon, offers her girdle to Hercules
(10) the cattle of Geryon secured by Hercules
(11) the apples of the Hesperides carried off by Hercules
(12) Cerberus captured and carried away by Hercules
Hercules in combat with heroes, etc.: first series
Hercules in combat with heroes, etc. (second series)
Hercules, mounted on Arion, the winged horse, sacks the city of Elis to take revenge on Augeas
Hercules, driving Geryon's cattle, has to fight the Ligurians; Jupiter assists Hercules by sending a shower of stones
Hercules, backed by the Thebans, fights the Minyans led by King Erginus of Orchomenus
Hercules sacks the city of Pylus; Mars and Juno are wounded; Periclymenus, Neleus' eldest son, after having assumed different shapes is killed in the form of an eagle by Hercules
campaign ~ Troy: Hercules' expedition against Laomedon, who had refused to reward him for the liberation of Hesione
Hercules kills the lion of Cithaeron
Hercules liberates Hesione, Laomedon's daughter, by killing the sea monster
Hercules rescues Alcestis
Hercules thrusts the rocks Calpe and Abyla apart, or forces the two rocks into temporary union
Juno sends Madness (Lyssa) to Hercules
Hercules kills his wife Megara and his children
Hercules cured of his madness by Minerva
Deianira sends Hercules a robe smeared with Nessus' blood
Hercules has himself carried to Mount Oeta and placed on a pyre
Hercules and Hebe
Theseus brought up in the palace of his grandfather Pittheus
Theseus takes the sword and the sandals of his father Aegeus from under the rock; usually in the presence of his mother Aethra
Theseus and Pirithous abducting Helen
the wedding-feast of Theseus and Phaedra
Theseus carried to the palace of the Nereids by dolphins; Thetis or Amphitrite gives him the ring and a jewelled crown
Theseus kills the Minotaur
Cercyon, king of Eleusis, wrestling with Theseus
Periphetes (Corunetes), the cripple, is killed with his own club by Theseus, who henceforth uses it
Procrustes (Damastes), who tied travellers on a bed and lengthened or shortened them according to their size, is killed by Theseus
Sciron, who made his victims wash his feet and then threw them into the sea, is killed by Theseus
Sinis, who used to tear his victims in two by tying them to two pine-trees which he bent down and then released, is killed by Theseus
Theseus captures the bull of Marathon
Theseus kills the wild sow Phaea of Crommyon
Theseus' fight with Pallas and his fifty sons
Theseus' fight with the Amazons when they attack Athens
Theseus in pursuit of Medea; she eludes him by casting a cloud about herself, and disappears in her chariot
Theseus and Pirithous before Pluto
Theseus and Pirithous suffering imprisonment in Hades, sitting on a rock
King Oeneus neglects Diana in his yearly sacrifices
the hunters assemble ~ Calydonian hunt
Atalanta and Meleager hunting
the wild boar is killed, usually by Meleager
Meleager gives the head of the boar to Atalanta
Meleager kills two of his uncles, when they object to the gift of the boar's head to Atalante
the war with Calydon, and the death of the surviving uncles
Althaea grieving at the death of her brothers
Apollo and/or the Muses teach the young Orpheus to play the lyre
Eurydice, while fleeing from Aristaeus, is killed by a snake
Orpheus descending into Hades with his lyre in his hand
Orpheus mourning Eurydice
Orpheus playing the lyre: trees and rocks move, beasts and birds are enchanted
the Thracian women throw Orpheus' head into the river Hebrus
the Muses collect Orpheus' limbs and bury them
Acrisius puts Danae and Perseus, her child by Jupiter, in a chest and casts it into the sea
Danae and Perseus, borne to the island of Seriphos, are found by Dictys, who was fishing there
Danae and Perseus taken to King Polydectes
Perseus reared by Polydectes
Perseus kills the sea monster (or turns it into stone by showing it the Gorgon's head) to release Andromeda; sometimes her parents Cepheus and Cassiopea watch the scene
Perseus frees Andromeda of her chains
Perseus cleanses his hands of blood at the well Hippocrene; Andromeda attended by Cupid and Naiads
Perseus shows Andromeda the head of Medusa mirrored in the water
Perseus and Andromeda married by Cepheus
Minerva gives Perseus the shield (or mirror)
Perseus beheading Medusa, with Pegasus, and possibly also Chrysaor, the warrior with the golden sword, springing from the blood of Medusa's head
Perseus flies over the Libyan desert, carrying the head of Medusa; the blood drops that fall from it change into snakes
Atlas turned into a mountain as punishment for his inhospitality
Polydectes is turned into stone while banqueting
Hyrieus entertaining Jupiter, Mercury and Neptune
Orion and Diana hunting
Orion finds his way to Vulcan's forge
Cedalion, Vulcan's apprentice, carried on Orion's shoulders, leads him over land and sea
Orion cured of his blindness by Apollo (Sol)
Orion is shot by Diana while swimming away from the scorpion
Orion is killed by Diana during the hunt
Diana implores Aesculapius to revive Orion
after Castor's death Pollux prays to Jupiter to let him die too, but Jupiter permits him to share his immortality with Castor; hence they spend their days alternatively on Olympus and in Hades
Stheneboea falsely accuses Bellerophon before Proetus
Bellerophon slings Stheneboea from Pegasus' back into the sea
Bellerophon bridles Pegasus, assisted by Minerva
Bellerophon flying on Pegasus
the Xanthian women, with their skirts hoisted to the waist, interfere; the waves retire and Iobates is convinced of Bellerophon's innocence
Oedipus is exposed: his feet are pierced and he is suspended from a tree
Oedipus is found by the shepherd Phorbas, who brings him to his master Polybus
Oedipus is reared by King Polybus of Corinth
Oedipus kills his father and attendants
the sphinx throws itself from the rock ~ Oedipus solving the riddle
Oedipus marries Jocasta, not knowing she is his mother
plague in Thebes
Tiresias explains the cause of the plague
Oedipus blinds himself
Oedipus driven from Thebes

Venus appears to Aeneas, who is just about to kill Helen, and advises him to flee
a miracle occurs in Aeneas' house: Ascanius' head catches fire but it does not harm him
'Pius Aeneas': Aeneas, leading Ascanius, escapes from burning Troy, carrying his father Anchises with the Penates; his wife Creusa, who sets out with them, is lost on the way
Aeneas searching for Creusa; her spirit appears to him
Aeneas builds a fleet
the fleet of Aeneas sets out
the Penates appear to Aeneas in a dream
the Harpy Celaeno foretells the future to Aeneas and his crew
on arrival in Sicily, Anchises, standing on the quarter-deck, offers unwatered wine and invokes the gods
the Trojans pass Charybdis ~ Aeneid
the Trojans meet Achaemenides, left behind by Ulysses in Polyphemus' cave, and take him with them
the Trojans escape from Polyphemus and the Cyclopes
death of Anchises
Aeneas and Achates go hunting for provisions
Venus covers Aeneas and Achates with a cloud
in the temple of Juno Aeneas and Achates look at scenes from the Trojan war depicted on the wall
Dido appears in the temple of Juno; a Trojan deputation asks her permission to beach and repair the ships
Dido leads Aeneas and his companions to her palace
Venus gives Cupid the form and features of Ascanius
Achates and Ascanius-Cupid on their way to Carthage with presents
Aeneas tells Dido of his wanderings
Juno and Venus agree that Aeneas shall marry Dido
Dido and Aeneas departing for the hunt
Dido and Aeneas shelter from the storm in a cave
Fama spreads the rumour of Dido's love-affair
Iarbas complains to Jupiter, who sends Mercury to Aeneas
Mercury summons Aeneas, engaged in building activities, to leave Carthage
Aeneas has his fleet put into readiness; complaints of Dido
death of Dido; she climbs the funeral pyre and falls upon the sword of Aeneas
Aeneas sacrificing at Anchises' grave: a snake appears
the contests held in memory of Anchises
the riding display by thirty-six youths led by Ascanius
a rain-storm extinguishes the fire lighted by the Trojan women
Anchises' spirit appears to Aeneas in his sleep
Aeneas leaves some of the Trojans under the protection of Acestes
Aeneas' fleet sails away; Hypnos puts Palinurus to sleep, who then falls overboard and is lost
Aeneas' fleet passes the Sirens
Misenus challenges Triton to a musical competition; he is dragged into the sea and is drowned by the god
the funeral of Misenus
Aeneas, guided by the Sibyl, enters the underworld through the cave of Avernus
Aeneas and the Sibyl reach the Styx, where they meet the ghosts of the unburied dead, among others Palinurus
Charon conveys Aeneas and the Sibyl in his boat; they alight at the gates of Pluto's kingdom
Cerberus is offered a drugged cake ~ Aeneas' visit to the underworld
Aeneas and the Sibyl meet various groups of the dead, among them is Dido, who turns aside
Aeneas and the Sibyl pass by Tartarus
Aeneas affixes the 'Golden Bough' to the threshold of Pluto's palace
Aeneas in the Elysian Fields
signs from heaven warn Latinus: a dense cloud of bees hangs upon the sacred laurel-tree
the Trojan embassy sent by Aeneas is welcomed by Latinus, who offers to make an alliance and to give Lavinia in marriage
Alecto flings a snake from her hair into the bosom of Latinus' wife Amata
Alecto, in the guise of an old woman, approaches Turnus in his sleep and sets him against Aeneas
when Ascanius is hunting, Alecto drives his hounds onto the trail of a sacred stag
Juno opens the gates of war
Aeneas' departure from Latium to secure help
Aeneas with Evander
Venus hands over the armour to Aeneas
the armour of Aeneas
Turnus blockades the Trojan camp
Nisus and Euryalus pass through the enemy lines at night
Ascanius' first deeds: he kills Numanus (Remulus), Turnus' brother-in-law
Turnus sweeps the battle-field and kills among others Bitias and Pandarus
assembly of the gods ~ Aeneas' return to the battle of Latium

Turnus opposes Aeneas and his troops on the beach

the spoils of Mezentius are offered to Mars
the body of Pallas is sent to Evander
a truce is arranged between the Trojans and the Latins to pay the last honours to the dead
gathering of the Latin leaders which is interrupted by the report that the Trojans are moving against the city
a cavalry engagement (~ battle of Latium) in which Camilla takes the lead

the fighting is resumed

Callisto as a bear wanders about miserably
Juno appoints Argus to watch the cow (Io metamorphosed)
Io as a cow watched by Argus
Jupiter orders Mercury to kill Argus
Mercury lulls Argus into sleep by making music
Io, still as a cow, is pursued by a gad-fly
Aesacus changed into a diving bird while pursuing the nymph Hesperia (or Asterope), who is bitten by a snake
Mercury bringing Argus' eyes to Juno; Juno sets Argus' eyes in the tail of her peacock
Circe changes Picus' companions, in search of their king, into various animals, because they threaten her (Ovid, Metamorphoses XIV 412)

Aedon, wife of Polytechnus, changed into a nightingale: when pursued by her husband for having slain her son Itys, Aedon, through the pity of Jupiter, is changed into a nightingale; Chelidon(is), Aedon's sister, and Polytechnus are also transformed into birds
Aedon, wife of Zethus, changed into a nightingale: in despair, because she has slain her son Itylus, Aedon is changed into a nightingale
Alcyone and Ceyx changed into kingfishers: when Alcyone finds the body of her husband Ceyx washed ashore, they are both changed into kingfishers (Ovid, Metamorphoses XI 741)
Anius' daughters changed into doves: to escape Agamemnon, who wishes to carry them with him to Troy, Anius' daughters are changed into doves by Bacchus (Ovid, Metamorphoses XIII 673)
Antigone changed into a stork: for comparing herself to Juno, the goddess changes Antigone, daughter of Laomedon, into a stork (Ovid, Metamorphoses VI 93)
Arne changed into a daw: for receiving gold as the price for betraying her fatherland to Minos, Arne is changed into a daw (Ovid, Metamorphoses VII 464)
Asteria changed into a quail: to escape the love of Jupiter, Asteria is changed into a quail
Coronis changed into a crow: to escape the love of Neptune, Coronis, daughter of Coroneus, is changed into a crow by Minerva (Ovid, Metamorphoses II 569)
Ctesylla changed into a dove: at Ctesylla's funeral, a dove springs from her body (Ovid, Metamorphoses VII 369)
Meleager's sisters changed into guinea-hens: while Meleager's sisters grieve at Meleager's death, they are changed into guinea-hens (Meleagrides) by Diana (Ovid, Metamorphoses VIII 539)
Nyctimene changed into an owl: because she feels ashamed of having committed incest with her father, Nyctimene is changed into an owl by Minerva (Ovid, Metamorphoses II 590)

Philomela, Procne and Tereus changed into nightingale, swallow, hoopoe (or hawk): Tereus seeks to kill Philomela and Procne for having slain his son; in their flight the two sisters are changed into a nightingale and a swallow; Tereus is changed into a hoopoe or a hawk (Ovid, Metamorphoses VI 668)
Pierides changed into magpies: the Pierides (Emathides) are changed into magpies by the Muses, who have defeated them in a musical contest (Ovid, Metamorphoses V 670)
the Pygmaean queen changed into a crane: as punishment for boasting herself fairer than Juno, the Pygmaean queen (Oinoe or Gerana) is changed into a crane by the goddess (Ovid, Metamorphoses VI 90)

Scylla changed into a lark: when falling from Minos' boat (or when throwing herself into the sea), Scylla, daughter of Nisus, is changed into a lark; she is then pursued by the hawk into which her father was transformed (Ovid, Metamorphoses VIII 145)
Semiramis changed into a dove: after her death, Semiramis, queen of Assyria, is changed into a dove (Ovid, Metamorphoses IV 47)
Theban women changed into birds: when grieving for the loss of Ino, the Theban women are changed into birds by Juno (Ovid, Metamorphoses IV 561)
Peristera changed into a dove: Peristera, who challenged Venus to a contest in picking flowers, is changed into a dove by Cupid, who was assisting his mother
Arethusa is turned into a fountain when pursued by the handsome hunter Alpheus (Pausanias V 7, 2)
