after their return to Canaan, Abraham worships God again in Bethel
the shepherds' quarrel ~ story of Abraham
Abraham gives Lot the choice of the surrounding country
Lot settles in Sodom
the king of Elam and three allied kings make war against the five rebellious kings of the Pentapolis
the king of Elam and three allied kings defeat the five rebellious kings of the Pentapolis; in flight, two of the five kings fall into lime-pits and the three others escape to the mountains
Sodom and Gomorrah are plundered; Lot is taken into captivity
the news of Lot's capture is brought to Abraham by a man who had escaped
Abraham calls all the men in his camp together and sets out in pursuit of the four kings
Melchizedek blesses Abraham
Abraham gives Melchizedek a tenth of the booty he has recovered
Abraham met by the king of Sodom (Genesis 14:21-24)
God promises that Abraham's seed shall be as numerous as the stars of heaven
God's promise to Abraham is guaranteed by a sacrifice
Abraham takes Hagar as his wife
Hagar, who is with child, despises the barren Sarah
Hagar ill-treated by Sarah
Hagar returns to Abraham
Abraham is circumcised
Ishmael and all the men of the household are circumcised
when Abraham is sitting by his house (or tent), three angels appear to him
Abraham kneels before the angels
Abraham fetches water and washes the angels' feet
Abraham entertaining the three angels
Abraham accompanying the departing angels
two angels on their way to Sodom
the angels find Lot sitting at the gateway of the city; he arises and kneels before them
Lot entertaining the angels
the angels advise Lot to leave the city
Lot's wife looks back at the city and is transformed into a pillar of salt
Sodom and Gomorrah burning
Lot, seeing the destruction of the cities and fearing for his safety in Zoar, flees with his daughters to a cave in the mountains
Lot's daughters make their father drunk
Lot's daughters give birth to Moab and Ben-ammi
Abraham's journey to Gerar
fearing for his life Abraham says of his wife 'she is my sister'; Abimelech has Sarah brought to him
the dream of Abimelech: God appears to him
Abraham is summoned before Abimelech; Sarah is given back to Abraham, who is honoured with a thousand pieces of silver and other gifts
Abraham praying for Abimelech
Isaac's circumcision
Sarah suckling Isaac
Abraham's feast on the day of Isaac's weaning
Sarah complains to Abraham about Ishmael
Abraham provides Hagar and Ishmael with bread and a jug of water
Hagar and Ishmael (often with bow and arrow) depart
Hagar and Ishmael in the wilderness
Abimelech and his army commander (Phichol) come to Abraham
Abraham complains about a well seized by Abimelech's servants
Abraham gives some sheep, oxen and ewe-lambs to Abimelech
Abimelech and Phichol taking leave from Abraham
Abraham plants a tree at Beersheba
Abraham with Isaac, an ass and the servants on their way to Moriah
preparations for the sacrifice, e.g. Abraham binding Isaac
Abraham picks up the knife to kill Isaac
a ram caught in a thicket is sacrificed instead of Isaac
the return to Beersheba ~ Abraham and Isaac
Abraham negotiating with Ephron over a sepulchre
Sarah's burial in the cave of Machpelah
reaching the city Eliezer has his camel kneel down by a well and prays for guidance
Rebekah at the well (Eliezer absent)
Rebekah draws water for the camels
Rebekah receives ear-rings and golden bracelets from Eliezer
Rebekah returns home
Laban, Rebekah's brother, comes to Eliezer at the well ~ Eliezer seeking a wife for Isaac
the marriage agreement ~ story of Isaac
gifts of clothing, gold and jewellery are offered to Rebekah's parents
Eliezer is entertained by Rebekah's parents
the leave-taking of Rebekah; Laban gives her provisions
Isaac, walking in the fields, meets Rebekah
Abraham is buried by Isaac and Ishmael in the cave of Machpelah
Esau, returning hungry from the hunt, sells his first birthright to Jacob for a pottage of lentils
God appears to Isaac and warns him not to journey into Egypt
Isaac denies that Rebekah is his wife
Isaac's prosperity as husbandman and herdsman
new wells are dug in the valley of Gerar
God appears to Isaac (journey to Beersheba)
Isaac builds an altar
the feast with Abimelech
Jacob bringing the goats to his mother
Rebekah preparing the meal for Isaac
Isaac sitting in bed blesses Jacob who, disguised in Esau's clothes, brings food to his father; Jacob's hands and neck are covered with goatskins
Jacob leaves the room ~ story of Isaac's blessing
Jacob threatened by Esau
Rebekah advises Jacob to flee
Isaac sends Jacob to his mother's relatives to seek a wife, and blesses him before his departure
Jacob's farewell
Jacob's journey to Haran
Esau marries Mahalath, daughter of Ishmael
the dream of Jacob: while sleeping on the ground with a stone for pillow Jacob sees a ladder reaching from earth to heaven with angels going up and down; usually with God at the top of the ladder
Jacob awakes, anoints the stone and names the place Bethel
Jacob vows exclusive worship to God
Jacob meets the shepherds of Haran and their flocks of sheep lying round the well
Jacob sees Rachel coming to the well to water Laban's sheep
Jacob moves the stone which covers the opening of the well and waters Rachel's sheep
Jacob kisses Rachel and is moved to tears
Rachel announces Jacob's arrival to Laban
Laban comes to meet Jacob at the well and brings him to his house
Jacob asks Laban's permission to marry Rachel
Jacob works as a herdsman for seven years in exchange for Rachel
Jacob requesting Rachel after the seven years
the wedding-feast; Laban substitutes Leah for Rachel
after the wedding-night Jacob discovers that he has been deceived with Leah and complains to Laban
the marriage of Jacob and Rachel
Jacob works for Laban seven more years
Leah bears four sons: Reuben, Simeon, Levi and Judah
Rachel complains to Jacob that she is childless
Leah gives her maid Zilpah to Jacob
Reuben brings mandrakes to his mother Leah
Leah bears two sons: Issachar, Zebulun, and a daughter Dinah
Rachel gives birth to Joseph
Laban agrees to give Jacob all the black and spotted sheep and goats as wages
the cattle are divided ~ Jacob's partnership with Laban
Jacob puts peeled rods in the animals' drinking troughs to make the beasts bear spotted young
Jacob is accused by Laban's sons
Jacob informing his wives Leah and Rachel of the departure
while Laban shears his sheep, Jacob and his wives prepare the leave-taking; Rachel steals her father's teraphim
Jacob on the way to Canaan with his family, his flocks, camels and all his possessions
Laban is told of Jacob's flight and sets off in pursuit with his men
Jacob is overtaken (by Laban)
God appears in a dream to Laban
Laban searches the tents and belongings of Jacob to find the teraphim
Jacob and Laban make an alliance: a pile of stone is erected and an animal is sacrificed
Jacob and Laban parting
Jacob is met by angels at Mahanaim
messengers are sent to Esau ~ story of Jacob
Jacob prays to God to save him from Esau
Jacob divides his people and the animals in two groups and sends some cattle on as a present to Esau
Jacob sends his family and caravan across the river Jabbok, and stays behind
Jacob wrestles with the angel (or man) till daybreak; Jacob's thigh is put out of joint
Jacob names the place Peniel
as Esau, usually represented as a soldier, approaches with four hundred men, Jacob divides the children among his wives
the meeting between Esau and Jacob
Esau returns to Seir
Jacob at Succoth where he builds a house
Jacob's journey
Jacob sets up his camp in a field near the city of Shechem
the rape of Dinah by Shechem
Shechem confesses his love for Dinah to his father Hamor
Hamor and Shechem come to Jacob, whose sons have just come in from the fields, to ask for Dinah in marriage; the sons agree on condition that the Shechemites will be circumcised
Shechem and Hamor propose the circumcision to their fellow-townsmen
Simeon and Levi kill all the Shechemites and bring Dinah home, while the other brothers plunder the city
Jacob reproving his sons
Jacob purges his house of idols
the journey to Bethel ~ story of Jacob
an altar is built at Bethel ~ story of Jacob
death of Rachel's nurse Deborah
God blesses Jacob, and names him Israel
Jacob sets up a pillar at Bethel; Jacob consecrates it by pouring oil on it
the departure from Bethel
birth of Benjamin: Rachel dies in childbirth
Jacob moves to the tower of Eder, and then to Hebron
Jacob's visit to Isaac ~ death of Isaac
Isaac is buried by Jacob and Esau
Judah marries the daughter of Shuah
the betrothal of Tamar and Er
Onan is told to marry Tamar
Tamar is sent back to her father's house
death of Judah's wife
Judah and Hirah the Adullamite go to Timnath, where Judah's sheep are being sheared
Tamar changes from her widow's clothes and covers her face with a veil after the manner of the prostitutes; sitting at the entrance of a city on the road to Timnath she awaits Judah
birth of the twins: Pharez and Zarah
first dream of Joseph: the eleven sheaves of wheat of his brothers form a circle round Joseph's sheaf and bow down
second dream of Joseph: the sun, moon and eleven stars make obeisance to Joseph
Joseph relating his dreams (the two dreams combined)
Jacob meditating upon Joseph's dreams
at Shechem Joseph meets a man who informs him that his brothers left for Dothan
Reuben intervenes in the plotting of Joseph's death
Joseph is thrown into a pit (usually depicted as a well or cistern)
Joseph is pulled out of the pit
Joseph is sold for twenty pieces of silver
Joseph's departure (after being sold by his brothers)
Joseph's brothers kill a kid
Jacob rending his garments on recognizing the robe
Joseph bewailed as dead by his father; the sons and daughters are unable to console him
Potiphar's wife catches Joseph by his robe, usually while lying in bed; Joseph escapes leaving his cloak behind in her hands (possibly with a naked child lying in a crib)
the butler's dream: the grape-vine with three branches whose fruit the butler squeezes into the king's cup
the baker's dream: birds pecking at three baskets of bread
first dream of Pharaoh: seven fat cows are devoured by seven lean cows ~ story of Joseph
second dream of Pharaoh: seven thin ears of corn devouring seven full ones ~ story of Joseph
interpretation of the dream of the lean and the fat cows
interpretation of the dream of the thin and the full ears of corn
the seven years of plenty (alleg.)
the seven years of famine (alleg.)
Joseph receives Asenath, daughter of the priest Potipherah, as wife
birth of Manasseh
birth of Ephraim
Asenath's conversion: she throws her idols out of the window
the conspiracy of Pharaoh's son against Joseph and Asenath
Joseph prepares for the famine and stores up corn
famine in Egypt sets in
Joseph drops wheat in the river
Jacob sends his ten sons to Egypt to buy corn, keeping the youngest, Benjamin, at home
Joseph accuses his brothers of being spies and throws them in prison
the brothers of Joseph recall the harm they did to him and repent; Joseph overhears the conversation and departs weeping
Joseph comes back, picks out Simeon and has him bound
at their camp one of Joseph's brothers finds money in his sack
Jacob refuses to have Benjamin taken to Egypt in spite of Reuben's exhortation
Jacob's farewell to Benjamin
Joseph orders a feast to be prepared in his house
at the door of Joseph's house his brothers talk with the steward; Simeon is brought to them
preparations for the feast at Joseph's house
on seeing Benjamin, Joseph is moved to tears and leaves the room
Joseph holding his divining-cup reveals the name and age of each of the brothers
Joseph's servants in pursuit of his brothers
the cup is found in Benjamin's sack
Joseph's brothers returning to the city
Joseph reveals his identity and in tears forgives his brothers' past misdeed
Joseph goes to Goshen to meet his father
Joseph makes the law that one-fifth of the production of the soil should belong to the king
Jacob blesses Manasseh and Ephraim with arms crossed; Joseph may be shown trying to uncross them or expressing (with Asenath) his disapproval
Jacob blesses Joseph
Jacob blessing Judah: 'Judah is a lion's whelp'
Jacob cursing Simeon and Levi
the descendants of Jacob's sons increase in number
Pharaoh commands the affliction of the Israelites
the Israelites are forced to hard labour ~ Exodus
Pharaoh orders Shiphrah and Puah, the two midwives, to kill all the Israelites' male infants
Pharaoh decrees the drowning of every new male offspring among the Israelites
the marriage of Moses' parents
Moses' birth
Moses is exposed in the ark on the banks of the Nile; Miriam, Moses' sister, keeps watch
the finding of Moses: Pharaoh's daughter comes to bathe with her maidens in the river and discovers the child floating on the water
Moses is either presented to Pharaoh's daughter or surrounded by women fondling him
when Moses is old enough, his mother brings him to Pharaoh's daughter, who adopts him
Moses is educated in the king's palace
Moses sees how the Israelites are forced to do hard labour
Moses at a well meets the seven daughters of Jethro, the priest of Midian
Moses is received in Jethro's house
Moses' marriage with Zipporah
Pharaoh's death
God looking upon the Israelites
while tending Jethro's flock Moses comes to Horeb
the burning bush ~ calling of Moses
Moses and Jethro parting ~ the calling of Moses
Moses departs for Egypt: he carries his rod and is accompanied by his wife and sons upon an ass
at an inn, God (or the angel of God) tries to kill Moses
God appears to Aaron
Moses and Aaron gather all the Israelite leaders
Pharaoh commands the taskmasters to stop supplying the people with straw for making bricks
the Israelites complain to Moses and Aaron (~ Pharaoh)
Moses instructing the Israelites
Moses and Aaron before Pharaoh; Aaron performs the miracle of the rod changing into a snake
recurrent scenes ~ the ten plagues
the ten plagues (part I)
the ten plagues (part II)
during the night Pharaoh sends for Moses and Aaron and begs them to depart
the Egyptians urging the Israelites to leave the country
the Israelites prepare to leave: the people fill their troughs with unleavened dough, wrap them in clothing and carry them on their shoulders
the Egyptians handing over their jewellery and clothing to the Israelites
the Israelites bake unleavened bread from the dough
the dedication of the first-born
Moses takes the bones of Joseph with him
the pillar of cloud and the pillar of fire ~ Exodus
Pharaoh is told of the flight of the Israelites
Moses lifts up his rod and the water divides (Red Sea); the angel of God and the pillar of cloud move to the rear
with his people safe on the shore, Moses raises his hands and causes the water to return; Pharaoh's army perishes in the water (Red Sea)
song of Moses ~ Exodus
Miriam takes up a tambourine and dances; all the women follow her
miracle of the sweetening of the water of Marah
the Israelites come to the oasis of Elim, where they find twelve springs and seventy palmtrees
in the desert of Sin Israel complains to Moses
Moses and Aaron promise food to the people
in the evening a large flock of quails flies into the Israelite camp
in the morning manna falls to the earth ~ Exodus
the Israelites come to Rephidim (or Meribah) and complain because there is no drinking-water
when Moses and Aaron pray in front of the tabernacle, God appears to them
Moses strikes the rock twice in front of the assembled people and water gushes out; the people quench their thirst
Moses instructing Joshua
Moses goes to the top of a hill with Aaron and Hur and raises his arms to make the Israelites victorious
Moses builds an altar
Jethro and Moses meeting
Jethro in Moses' tent
Jethro offers a sacrifice to God and eats bread with Moses, Aaron and all the leaders of Israel
Jethro, when seeing Moses busy the whole day settling disputes among the people, advises him to appoint some judges
Moses choosing judges
Moses and Jethro parting ~ Jethro's visit to Moses in the desert
Moses (alone) ascending Mount Sinai
Moses communicating with God on Mount Sinai (the mountain may be covered by a thick cloud)
Moses coming down from Mount Sinai
Moses addressing the elders
Moses addressing the Israelites
the Israelites come to Mount Sinai and set up camp at the foot of the mountain
the people get ready for the coming legislation: they wash their clothes and set bounds round the mountain
Mount Sinai is covered by a thick cloud, thunder and lightning
Moses writing down the law
Moses builds an altar and sets up twelve stones
the young men bring offerings; Moses takes half the blood of the animals and sprinkles it on the altar
Moses reading the book of the covenant to the people
Moses takes the bowls with the other half of the sacrificial blood and sprinkles it on the people
Moses ascends the mountain with Aaron, Nadab, Abihu and seventy leaders
Moses tells the elders to stay behind and ascends Mount Sinai further with Joshua
Moses receives the tables of the law from God
the people ask Aaron to make some idols
Aaron makes a golden calf and has it placed on a pedestal or altar
adoration of the golden calf (which may be standing on a pillar, and is sometimes depicted as a dragon)
Moses (and Joshua) come(s) down with the stone tablets
Moses melts the calf, grinds the gold into fine powder, mixes it with water and makes the people drink it
Moses calls Aaron to account
Moses, standing at the gate of the camp, causes the Levites to kill all the idolaters
God sends a plague on the people
God relents and sends an angel who will guide the people to Canaan
the people mourn and take off their jewellery ~ punishment of the idolators
when Moses abides in the tabernacle, the pillar of cloud comes down and stays at the door; the people gather at the entrance of their tents and bow down in reverence
Moses, standing on a cliff, sees God from behind
Moses cuts two stone tablets
Moses carries the two stone tablets up Mount Sinai
God renews the covenant with Moses and writes the law on the tablets
Moses comes down with the new tablets and is awaited by Aaron and the assembled people, who notice that 'his face is shining' (Moses' face is depicted with rays of light or with horns)
the people bring their offerings for the Tabernacle: all kinds of fine objects, jewellery, linen, etc.
Moses appoints Bezaleel, Aholiab and other craftsmen
the making of the Tabernacle and its accessories ~ Exodus
the completion of the Tabernacle and its accessories; Moses examines everything and blesses the craftsmen
the Tabernacle is set up and Moses puts the ark with the tables in it
the first numbering of the people ~ book of Numbers
the Levites are appointed to serve the priests
the unclean are expelled from the camp ~ the book of Numbers
offerings of the leaders of the tribes at the dedication of the Tabernacle
Aaron lights the Tabernacle lamps
celebration of the second Passover
signals for breaking camp ~ book of Numbers
the Israelites break camp and start on their journey ~ the book of Numbers
Moses entreats Hobab, Jethro's son, to come with them
at Taberah the people are punished by fire which consumes one end of the camp
Moses chooses seventy elders to assist him and places them round the Tabernacle; the spirit of God descends upon them
a multitude of quail falls and covers the camp
the Israelites move to Hazeroth
Aaron and Miriam complaining of Moses
God comes down in the pillar of cloud at the door of the Tabernacle and rebukes Aaron and Miriam
Miriam is punished with leprosy; Moses prays to God, who promises to heal Miriam after seven days
the Israelites leave Hazeroth for the desert of Pharan
Moses sends out twelve spies to explore the land of Canaan
the spies take away some of the fruits of Canaan and return, usually carrying a large bunch of grapes on a pole
the spies, except for Caleb and Joshua, bring startling reports which upset the people ~ reconnaissance of Canaan
the people complain ~ reconnaissance of Canaan
all the spies, except for Joshua and Caleb, fall ill and die ~ reconnaissance of Canaan
when Moses reports God's punishment to the people they mourn bitterly ~ reconnaissance of Canaan
the first attempt to invade Canaan fails: the Israelites are smitten by the Amalekites
a man found gathering wood on the sabbath is brought before Moses and Aaron
the sabbath-breaker is stoned to death ~ the book of Numbers
Korah and two hundred and fifty adherents assemble before Moses and Aaron; Moses challenges the rebels to offer incense to the Lord
Moses reproving Korah
Moses taunted by Dathan and Abiram, who refuse to appear before him
Korah and his followers, holding censers, face Moses and Aaron before the door of the Tabernacle (or beside an altar); the rebels are destroyed by fire of the Lord
the priest Eleazar gathers the censers from the remains of the men who have been burnt
the people complain about the death of the rebels (Korah, Dathan and Abiram)
Moses receives twelve rods, one for each tribe, and lays them in the Tabernacle
Aaron's rod has sprouted, flowered and produced ripe almonds
death and burial of Miriam
the king of Edom refuses to let Israel pass
Moses ascends Mount Hor with Aaron and Eleazar
Moses removes Aaron's priestly robes and puts them on Eleazar
Aaron's burial
the people mourn for Aaron
when the people complain again about the food, God sends poisonous snakes; many die of snake-bites ~ book of Numbers
a serpent of brass is made and is set on a pole
anyone who is bitten by a snake is cured by looking at the brazen serpent; the serpent (or dragon) is usually depicted on a tau-shaped cross or on a pillar
a well is dug at Beer
messengers of the Israelites are sent to the Amorite King Sihon
battle of the Israelites against the Amorites during their journey through the desert
the Israelites settle in the towns of the Amorites after their victory over King Sihon
Moses sends spies to the city of Jaazer
battle of the Israelites against King Og
the Moabite King Balak, alarmed by the arrival of the Israelites, sends messengers to Balaam to pronounce a curse on them
Balaam receives the messengers of the Moabite King Balak
new messengers are sent to Balaam
an angel holding a sword bars the way and causes Balaam's ass to turn aside; the angel is invisible to Balaam
Balaam and King Balak meet and together they make a sacrifice
Balaam the prophet is rebuked by King Balak
Balaam's final prophecies ~ the Israelites: 'star of Jacob'
Balaam parting from Balak
the Israelites and the Moabite women
Zimri takes a Midianite woman, Cozbi, into his tent, while the people are lamenting at the entrance of the Tabernacle on account of an epidemic
Moses commanding the attack on the Midianites
all the Midianite men, including their five kings and Balaam, are killed; the women, children and animals are captured, and the cities are burnt
the Israelite army returns with the spoils after the battle against the Midianites
division of the spoils after the battle of the Israelites against the Midianites
the country east of the Jordan is given to the tribes of Reuben, Gad and half of the tribe of Manasseh
Moses petitioned by the heads of the Gilead family, who want the daughters of Zelophehad not to marry outside their own tribe
Joshua instructs the officers, and is accepted as the new leader of the Israelites
Joshua sends two spies to explore Jericho
story of Rahab and the spies
the Israelites move their camp to the Jordan, waiting to cross it
the Israelites leave their camp to cross the Jordan; the priests, carrying the ark, lead the march
the crossing of the Jordan by the Israelites
at Gilgal Joshua erects another monument with the twelve stones taken from the Jordan
Israelites born during the wandering are circumcised after the crossing of the river Jordan
the Passover is celebrated for the first time in the promised land
Joshua encounters an angel holding a sword (at first not recognizing the angel, Joshua may be shown drawing his sword)
Jericho shuts itself up within its walls and prepares to withstand the siege

the Israelites march around Jericho: in the procession the main body of the soldiers comes first, next are seven priests who blow on trumpets, followed by the priests carrying the ark and a rear guard
Joshua sends spies to Ai, who report that the city is not large
only three thousand men go up against Ai; they are driven back and some of them are slain
Joshua, prostrate before the Tabernacle, mourns and tears his clothes after the first unsuccessful attack on the city of Ai
Joshua investigates the tribes after the unsuccessful attack on the city of Ai: the tribe of Judah is selected and finally Achan is picked out
Achan confesses to have taken from the spoils a garment and some silver and gold
Achan, his family and possessions (including the stolen spoils) are taken to the valley of Achor to be stoned
a huge pile of stones is put over Achan and his family, stoned to death because Achan had stolen from the spoils of Jericho
Joshua commands some of his soldiers to go into hiding west of the city of Ai
Joshua and the rest of the army set up camp on the north side of the city of Ai
when the king of Ai comes out to fight the Israelites, they retreat and pretend to flee from the enemy
the king of Ai is brought to Joshua and hanged
Joshua sets up an altar on Mount Ebal
the Israelites offer burnt sacrifices on Mount Ebal
Joshua writes on the stones a copy of the law and reads it aloud to the whole congregation, women and children included
the people of Gibeon, fearing Joshua and his men, decide to deceive them: they load their donkeys with worn-out sacks, they put on ragged clothes and old sandals and take decaying food
the people of Gibeon, dressed up in rags, and pretending to have come from a distant land ask Joshua to make a treaty with them
the outwitted Israelites solemnly make an alliance with the Gibeonites
the trick of the Gibeonites is found out; Joshua decrees that thenceforth they must be the servants of the Israelites, they must cut wood and carry water
the five Amorite kings (viz. from Jerusalem, Hebron, Jarmuth, Lachish and Eglon) join forces to attack Gibeon
the city of Gibeon being besieged, the inhabitants ask Joshua for help
by night Joshua and his army come to the rescue of Gibeon
Joshua and his army make a surprise attack on the Amorites who are besieging the city of Gibeon
the five Amorite kings escape and hide in the cave of Makkedah
the kings of the north rallied around Jabin, king of Hazor, muster their armies with many horses and chariots near the waters of Merom
the kings of the north are defeated by Joshua, who burns their chariots and cripples their horses by cutting the hamstrings
the city of Hazor is captured and burned by Joshua and his army; the inhabitants are put to the sword
the giant race of Anakim is defeated by Joshua and his army
Joshua assigns the city of Hebron to Caleb
the Tabernacle is set up at Shiloh
Joshua tells the tribes, who had not been assigned their share, to explore the region and to write a description of the land
Joshua (assisted by Eleazar) casts lots and assigns to each of the remaining seven tribes a certain part of Canaan
six cities of refuge are designated to provide sanctuary for murderers
Joshua sends the tribes of Reuben and Gad, and part of Manasseh's tribe back home, and exhorts them to keep the law
at Gilead, at the borders of the Jordan, the two and a half tribes build a large altar (Reubenites, Gadites, half of Manasseh's tribe)
Joshua being very old calls the Israelites together to hear his final exhortations
death and burial of Joshua
the bones of Joseph are buried at Shechem
death and burial of Eleazar the high priest
the tribes of Judah and Simeon defeat the Canaanites and Perizzites
Adoni-bezek is caught; his thumbs and his great toes are cut off
Achsah and Othniel ask Caleb for a field and springs of water (Achsah dismounting from her donkey)
the Moabites are defeated by Ehud and his army near the fords of the river Jordan
Sisera flees to the tent of Jael, who goes out to meet him
Sisera asks for water and is given milk by Jael
Jael takes a nail of the tent and a hammer
Jael kills the sleeping Sisera by hitting the nail through his temples
Barak comes to Jael's tent; she shows him Sisera's body
the angel of the Lord appears to Gideon, who is usually shown threshing wheat
command of the angel of the Lord to Gideon: save Israel from the Midianites
at his calling (when he is threshing wheat) Gideon asks for a sign from the Lord
after his calling by the angel of the Lord Gideon fears and is reassured
the Lord commands Gideon to destroy the altar of Baal, which had been built on his father's land
Gideon and ten servants destroy the altar of Baal, cut down the grove near it, build an altar to God on the rock, take a bullock and offer a burnt sacrifice
the men of the city see the destroyed altar (story of Gideon)
Joash, Gideon's father, and the men of the city who want Gideon to be put to death because he had destroyed the altar of Baal
the Midianites invade the valley of Jezreel
Gideon blows a trumpet, sends out messengers and assembles the people of Israel for a raid against the Midianites
twice Gideon asks the Lord to show him a sign with a sheep's fleece before his raid against the Midianites
to select an army for a raid against the Midianites Gideon sends away the fearful and brings the remaining ten thousand men to the water
those who lap water by putting their hand to their mouth are separated from those who kneel down to drink the water ~ selection of Gideon's men
Gideon's army, three hundred warriors, take up victuals and their trumpets
in the night Gideon goes to the Midianite camp with his servant Phurah
Gideon overhears a Midianite telling about his dream of a cake of barley bread
Gideon divides his men into three companies
the attack on the Midianites: Gideon and his men blow their trumpets, break their pitchers, and hold their lamps
pursuit of the Midianites by Gideon's men
the Midianites cut off from the waters by the Ephraimites
Oreb and Zeeb are captured and killed by the Ephraimites; their heads are brought to Gideon
the dissatisfied Ephraimites are pacified by Gideon
Gideon demands bread for his hungry soldiers
Gideon pursues Zebah and Zalmunna, the two kings of Midian, and takes them prisoner
Gideon punishes Succoth and Penuel
Gideon kills Zebah and Zalmunna
Gideon refuses government over Israel
Gideon asks and is given the ear-rings of the slain Midianites
Gideon dies and is buried
Abimelech incites his family in Shechem to support him rather than his brothers, the seventy sons of Gideon
Abimelech receives support from his mother's brothers who give him seventy pieces of silver
Abimelech, with hired men, kills his brothers on one stone, except for Jotham who hides himself
Abimelech is made king in Shechem
on the top of Mount Gerizim, Jotham tells his fable of the kingship of the trees
disagreement between the Shechemites and Abimelech
the tower of Shechem
the tower of Thebez; death of Abimelech
the Israelites worship Baal, Ashtaroth, and other idols
Israel is oppressed by the Ammonites
